That taste is also what is tasted.
Question:
If so, what is the difference between taste and what is tasted?
Answer:ğŸ”½What is tasted is included in one of the seventeen sense bases, one of the eleven sense fields, and one of the four aggregates.
Taste is included in one of the sense bases, one of the sense fields, and one of the four aggregates.
Furthermore, some say that meaning is form and non-form, while text is non-form.
Like form and non-form, it is associated and not associated, has support and no support, has efficacy and no efficacy, has activity and no activity, has objects and no objects.
Text is not associated, up to having no objects.
Furthermore, some say that meaning is visible and invisible, while text is invisible.
Meaning is resistant and non-resistant, while text is non-resistant.
Meaning is contaminated and uncontaminated, while text is contaminated.
Meaning is conditioned and unconditioned, while text is conditioned.
The meaning is good, bad, and neutral, while the text is neutral.
The meaning may be worldly or transcendent, while the text is worldly.

The meaning may be bound to the three realms or unbound, while the text is bound to the desire and form realms.ğŸ”½The meaning may be of learners, post-learners, or neither, while the text is neither.
The meaning may be eliminated by the path of seeing, the path of cultivation, or not eliminated, while the text is eliminated by the path of cultivation.
The meaning may be defiled or undefiled, while the text is undefiled.
Like defiled and undefiled, with faults and without faults, black and white, hidden and unhidden, regressing and non-regressing, with retribution and without retribution.
The text is undefiled up to having no retribution.
The difference between text and meaning is called distinction.
As the sutra says:
What is a name?
The four aggregates are a name.
Question:
Since names are categorized as mental activities not directly associated with thought, why did the World-Honored One say that the four aggregates, not the form aggregate, are names?
Answer:
The Buddha said that form and non-form are divided into two parts, with all form being the form aggregate and all non-form being the four aggregates.
All names that express meanings are included in the mental factors not directly associated with thought.
There are six kinds of names, namely merit, place of birth, time, desire, action, and characteristic.

Merit as a name is like one who recites the sutras being called a sutra master, one who recites the Vinaya being called a Vinaya master, and one who recites the Abhidharma being called an Abhidharma master. By attaining the fruit of stream-entry, one is called a stream-enterer, and up to one who attains the fruit of arhatship being called an arhat.
Place of birth as a name is like one born in a city being called a city person, and thus one born in any country being called a person of that country.
Time as a name is like one in childhood being called a child, and one in old age being called an old person.

Names according to desire are like when parents give a name at birth, or when Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmans give a name. Names according to action are like being called a painter because of painting, or being called a coppersmith because of working with copper and iron.
Names according to characteristics are like being called a staff-bearer because of carrying a staff, or being called an umbrella-bearer because of holding an umbrella.
There is another explanation: There are four kinds of names, namely, one, conceptualization;
two, mutual;ğŸ”½three, designation;
four, samÄsa.
Names according to conceptualization are like when a noble person is named after a slave, or when a poor person is named after a noble person.
Names according to mutual are like being called a crawling worm because of crawling on the belly.
Names according to designation are like being called a worshipper of Viá¹£á¹‡u because of worshipping Viá¹£á¹‡u, or being called a son of BrahmÄ because of being born from BrahmÄ.
As for those named after their characteristics, it is like a cow with a mottled color being called a mottled cow, or a person belonging to a king being called a king's man.
Furthermore, there are those who say that names are of two kinds, namely innate and created.
As for innate names, it is like the Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, and Shudras.
As for created names, it is like when parents give a name at birth, or when Shakyas and Brahmins give a name.
Furthermore, there are those who say that innate names are like when parents give a name at birth, or when Shakyas and Brahmins give a name.
As for created names, later on friends and acquaintances give another name, which is called the second name.
Furthermore, there are those who say that there are two kinds of names, namely with characteristics and without characteristics.
As for names with characteristics, it is like impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self, and the names of the aggregates and sense bases.
As for names without characteristics, it is like the names of sentient beings, humans, and Narayana.
If a Buddha appears in the world, there are names with characteristics. If a Buddha does not appear in the world, there are only names without characteristics.
Again, some say there are two kinds of names, namely common and uncommon.
Uncommon names are like the names of the Three Jewels.
Common names are the remaining names.
Again, some say all names are common, with no uncommon names.
Why is this?
One meaning can be established with all names, and all meanings can be established with one name.
Again, some say there are two kinds of names, namely definite and indefinite.
Definite names are like Mount Sumeru, the four continents, and the great ocean. When this world was first formed, these were definite names.
Indefinite names are the remaining names.
Again, some say there are no definite names.
Why is this?
In other border regions, Mount Sumeru and others are given other names.
Commentary:
Those who say this are good. When the world first formed, the names of Mount Sumeru, the four continents, and the great oceans were also like this.
Question:
When the eon ends, everything is scattered and destroyed. Who created these names again?
Answer:
Some say that the sage entered concentration and transmitted these names again.
Some say that sentient beings have the power of causes and can speak these names.
Question:
Are the names transmitted by common consent, or are there new creators?
Answer:
When the world first formed, the names of Mount Sumeru and others were transmitted by common consent, but other names are not fixed.
Some say that there are two kinds of names, namely substance and action.
Names of substance are like Devadatta and YajÃ±adatta.
Names of action are like the names of the doer, the cutter, the cooker, and the reader.
Question:
Is there anyone who knows the limit of names?
Answer:
There is, only the Buddha can, others do not know.
Why is it so?
Because the Buddha can know the limit of all names, he is called the Omniscient One.
As the sutra says:
When the Tathagata appears in the world, then the appearance of names and so forth appears in the world.
Question:

Whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, names and so forth always appear in the world. Why is it said that when the Tathagata appears in the world, then the appearance of names and so forth appears in the world?
Answer:

As for the name-body and so forth that appear in the world, namely the names of aggregates, realms, and entrances, they accord with no-self, accord with liberation, accord with emptiness, cut off the view of persons, give rise to the thought of enlightenment, turn away from afflictions, head towards liberation, stop delusion, give rise to wisdom, cut off doubt, give rise to certainty, become weary of birth and death, delight in tranquility, cut off the intentions of non-Buddhists, praise the intentions of Buddhists. Speaking such name-bodies is called appearing in the world.
Question:
Is the name of fire, such as fire, a name with characteristics or a name without characteristics?
Answer:
It is a name with characteristics.
As explained above, all names that manifest meanings have characteristics.
Question:
If so, what are the characteristics of fire?
Answer:
There are two kinds of meanings:
with characteristics and without characteristics.
Like fire, externally there are no characteristics of fire, so it is said to be without characteristics.
It is like saying that flame is the characteristic of fire, and that there is the characteristic of fire.
The Buddha's sutras have three kinds of names for teaching the Dharma, namely, past, present, and future.
Question:
What is the essential nature of these three kinds of names for teaching the Dharma?
Answer:
As the PÄrÄyaá¹‡a SÅ«tra says, the essential nature of the three kinds of names for teaching the Dharma is included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates.
Question:
As the PÄrÄyaá¹‡a SÅ«tra says that the essential nature of the three kinds of teaching the Dharma is included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates.

What is spoken is speech, and what is revealed is names, which should be one element, one sense base, and one aggregate, but why is it said to be included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates?
Answer:
Some say that it is because the three kinds of names for teaching the Dharma and their retinue are taken.
What is the matter?
Answer:
Speech can give rise to names, and names can reveal meaning, so it is said along with their retinue.
There is also an explanation that the Dharma is spoken for three meanings, so it is said that the three are called speaking the Dharma.
Why is it so?
Because the speaker and the listener are both for the sake of the meaning, this is why it completely includes the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
The question is asked:
Why is it that conditioned dharmas are called these three names and spoken of, but unconditioned dharmas are not spoken of?
The Venerable Vasumitra answers:
This sÅ«tra speaks of conditioned dharmas, and conditioned dharmas cannot be made into a fourth or fifth speaking of the Dharma.
There is also an explanation that this sÅ«tra speaks of all dharmas, and unconditioned dharmas fall within the present world.
Why is it so?
Because present dharmas are able to realize and attain unconditioned dharmas.
For this reason, unconditioned dharmas are also included within the three kinds of speaking of the Dharma.
There is also an explanation that if there are three natures, these three names are spoken of and the Dharma is spoken.
The three natures refer to speech, names, and meanings.
Although unconditioned dharmas are said to have meaning, they are without words and names. Therefore, it is said that they are not included in the three kinds of named dharmas.
Question:
Why did the World-Honored One say that the world is the three kinds of named dharmas?
Answer:
Some say that it is in order to stop the intentions of non-Buddhists, because non-Buddhists are foolish regarding the world.
Some also say that it is in order to destroy the intentions of those in the future who say that the past and future do not exist, and therefore say that the world is the three kinds of named dharmas.
Some also say that non-Buddhists make the following statement:
If there is no self, then the person's teaching of the Dharma will ultimately be purposeless.
In order to destroy such intentions, it is said:
Although there is no self, it is taught for the sake of the world.

Question:ğŸ”½If the Dharma is taught for the sake of the past, one understands future and present matters;ğŸ”½if the Dharma is taught for the sake of the future, one understands past and present matters;
if the Dharma is taught for the sake of the present, one understands future and past matters.
Among the three kinds of named teachings, which one is it?
Answer:
Some say that this kind of teaching is different from the three kinds of named teachings.
Furthermore, some say that if one teaches the past, and understands future and present matters, it is the past, belonging to the past world.
Understanding future and present matters, it is included in the future and present worlds.
Up to teaching the present, the past and future are also like this.
Furthermore, some say that if one teaches in this way, it is the meaning of the three worlds.
If it is taught for the past, it is the meaning of the past.
Understanding the future and present, it is the meaning of the future and present.
The future and present are also like this.
As the sutra says:
There are three kinds of named teachings, with no fourth or fifth.
It is asked:
If the three kinds are mentioned, it is said that there is teaching and understanding of the Dharma, and the meaning is already sufficient. Why is it further said that there is no fourth or fifth?
Answer:
As for no fourth, it denies the existence of a fourth time;
As for no fifth, it determines that there is no fifth time.
Furthermore, some say: As for no fourth, it denies the fourth time; as for no fifth, it denies unconditioned dharmas.
Furthermore, some say: The four kinds should be mentioned, namely the four noble truths.
As for no fifth, there is no fifth truth.
As for no sixth, it denies space and non-analytical cessation.
Furthermore, some say: There should be five kinds, namely the five aggregates.
As for no sixth, there is no sixth aggregate.
As for no seventh, it denies unconditioned dharmas.
This is because the three times are called the teaching of the Dharma, so there is no fourth or fifth.
There should be one kind called expounding the Dharma, namely contemplation, without a second or third.
Without a second means there is no second contemplation.
Without a third means to exclude dharmas not included in contemplation.
Furthermore, some say there should be two kinds called expounding the Dharma, namely concentration and wisdom.
Without a third means there is no second concentration or second wisdom.
Without a fourth means to exclude dharmas not included in concentration and wisdom.
Because this explains the three times as expounding the Dharma, there is no fourth or fifth.
Without a fourth means to exclude the fourth time.
Without a fifth means to exclude dharmas not included in the three times.

Using this method of enumeration, one should explain the three gates of liberation, the four truths, the five aggregates, the six aspects of the holy life, the seven factors of enlightenment, the eightfold path, the nine successive concentrations, and the ten kinds of dharmas of one beyond training.
The ten powers of the TathÄgata should have ten kinds of names for expounding the Dharma, without an eleventh or twelfth.
Without an eleventh means without an eleventh power.
Without a twelfth means to exclude dharmas not included in the ten powers.
That sÅ«tra says:
One should examine a person in four ways to see if they are suitable to speak with or not.
What are the four?
First, not abiding in the distinction between proper and improper;
second, not abiding in the treatises on knowledge;
third, not abiding in discrimination;
fourth, not abiding in the traces of the path.
Question:
What is the difference between these four things?
Answer:
Some say: Not abiding in the distinction between proper and improper means not truly knowing what is proper and improper.
Not abiding in the treatises on knowledge means not truly knowing knowledge and ignorance.
Not abiding in discrimination means not truly knowing the conventional truth and ultimate truth.
Those who do not abide in the traces of the path do not know this body's path of accumulation as it really is, nor do they know this body's path of cessation as it really is.

Furthermore, some say: Those who do not abide in what is possible and impossible know the eye and form that can give rise to eye-consciousness, up to the mind and dharmas that can give rise to mental consciousness, which is called what is possible.
Not knowing as it really is is called not abiding.
Not abiding in the treatises on knowledge is not knowing the ten knowledges as they really are.
Not abiding in discrimination is not knowing the sÅ«tras of definitive meaning and non-definitive meaning as they really are.
Not abiding in the traces of the path is not knowing the four kinds of traces of the path as they really are.
Furthermore, some say: Those who do not abide in what is possible and impossible cannot determine for themselves what is possible and impossible.
Those who do not abide in the treatises on knowledge cannot endure the discrimination of questions and answers before and after.
Those who do not abide in discrimination do not know deception and truth as they really are.
Those who do not abide in the traces of the path do not delight in the mind when asked about the Dharma by others.
There is another explanation: Not abiding in the right and wrong means not distinguishing between existence and non-existence.
Not abiding in the treatises of knowledge means not understanding the treatises of wise people.
Not abiding in discrimination means not knowing the words there is no such thing in hypothetical situations.
Not abiding in the traces of the path means not having the corresponding enlightened mind.
There is another explanation: Not abiding in the right and wrong means not distinguishing one's own meaning and others' meaning in the discussion.
Not abiding in the treatises of knowledge means clinging to and not letting go of what one has heard before, and being unable to contemplate the meaning of what one hears later.
Not abiding in discrimination means doubting the correct meaning spoken by others, like a person seeing ghee and calling it rice porridge.
Not abiding in the traces of the path means not recognizing the sequence spoken by others, taking the previous as the middle and the middle as the latter.
There is another explanation: Not abiding in the right and wrong means not knowing the matters that can be understood or not understood in the present.
Those who do not abide in the treatise on knowledge are unable to use inferential thoughts to measure what is discussed.
Those who do not abide in discrimination do not know the sequence of what is said before and after.
Those who do not abide in the traces of the path do not understand the meaning of others' questions.
Venerable Vamalakal spoke:
Those who do not abide in the proper and improper are unable to determine what is said.
Those who do not abide in the treatise on knowledge do not know what is deceitful and what is true.
Those who do not abide in discrimination are unable to bear the discrimination of questions and answers before and after.
Those who do not abide in the traces of the path are not pleased with others' discussions in accordance with the Dharma.
Venerable Saá¹ƒghabhadra spoke:
Those who do not abide in the proper and improper do not know the meaning of the proper and improper in the SÅ«tra on the Many Realms.
Those who do not abide in the treatise on knowledge do not know the essence and divisions of the forty-four knowledges and seventy-seven knowledges.
Those who do not abide in discrimination do not know the afflictions and the way out.
Those who do not abide in the stages do not know the path to the cessation of form as it truly is.
One should also examine a person in four ways: this elder should answer definitively when asked a definitive question, and so on.
What is a definitive question?
If asked whether the Buddha is a fully enlightened one,
one should answer definitively, saying:
Yes.
Is this Buddha Dharma good and excellent?
One should answer definitively, saying:
Yes.
Are these disciples of the Buddha a harmonious assembly?
One should answer definitively, saying:
Yes.
Are all conditioned things impermanent, all conditioned things suffering, and nirvana peaceful?
One should answer definitively, saying:
Yes.
This is called a definitive question.
Question:
Why does one answer definitively when asked in this way?
Answer:

This question increases the benefit and goodness of the meaning, and also advances the holy life, penetrates the factors of enlightenment, and can attain nirvana. Therefore, one who asks in this way makes a definitive answer in the treatise.
What is a treatise that answers by discrimination?
The answer is:
If one asks in this way:
Speak the Dharma for me.
One should answer in this way:

The Dharma is also numerous, past, future, and present, wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate, bound to the desire realm, bound to the form realm, bound to the formless realm, unbound, learner, non-learner, neither learner nor non-learner, to be abandoned by the path of seeing, to be abandoned by the path of cultivation, and unabandoned.
Such dharmas, which Dharma should be spoken?
In this way, according to the question, one should answer by discrimination. This is called a treatise that answers by discrimination.
What is a treatise that answers by counter-questioning?
The answer is:
As it is said:
Speak the Dharma for me.

One should answer in this way:ğŸ”½The Dharma is also numerous, past, future, and present, wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate, bound to the desire realm, bound to the form realm, bound to the formless realm, unbound, learner, non-learner, neither learner nor non-learner, to be abandoned by the path of seeing, to be abandoned by the path of cultivation, and unabandoned.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The dharmas are also numerous, including those that are past and those that are not yet eliminated.
Among these dharmas, which dharma are you speaking of?
This is called a counter-questioning answer.
The question says:
What is the difference between a discriminating answer and a counter-questioning answer?
The answer says:
If speaking in terms of the answer, there is no difference.
If speaking in terms of the question, there should be a difference.
Why is this?
There are two kinds of questions:
There are those who ask in order to understand the meaning, and those who ask in order to provoke.
If one asks in order to understand the meaning, for the sake of those who speak of the Dharma, one should answer like this:
The dharmas are also numerous, including those that are past and those that are not yet eliminated.
Among these dharmas, which dharma are you speaking of?
If one says, Speak the dharmas of the past for me,
One should answer like this:
The past dharmas are also numerous, including the wholesome, the unwholesome, and the indeterminate.
If one says:
Speak the wholesome dharmas for me,
One should answer like this:
There are also many wholesome dharmas, from form up to consciousness.
If one says:
Speak the dharma of form for me.
One should answer like this:
Form is also numerous, from not killing living beings up to not speaking falsely.
If one says:
Speak the dharma of not killing living beings for me.
One should answer like this:
Not killing has three kinds, arising from non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion. Which one do you want me to speak?
If one says:
Speak the one arising from non-greed for me.
One should answer like this:
That arising from non-greed has two kinds:
action and non-action.
If one asks in order to know the meaning, one should explain and speak in sequence.
If one asks in order to cause trouble, one should answer:
Dharmas are also numerous, which dharma do you want me to speak?
One should not say:
There are past, future, up to uninterrupted.
If one says:
Speak the past dharma for me.
You should answer like this:
Past dharmas are also numerous.
You should not speak of wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
If you say:
Speak the wholesome dharmas for me.
You should answer like this:
Wholesome dharmas are also numerous.
You should not speak of form up to consciousness.
If you say:
Speak the form for me.
You should answer like this:
Form is also numerous.
You should not speak of not killing up to not engaging in frivolous speech.
If you say:
Speak the not killing for me.
You should answer like this:
Not killing is also numerous.
You should not speak of arising from non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion.
If you say:
Speak the one arising from non-greed for me.
You should answer like this:
Arising from non-greed is also numerous.
You should not speak of action and non-action.
If one is asked in this way to trouble oneself, one should answer in this way until the question is exhausted, or sometimes answer oneself.

There are those who ask because they seek good meaning, there are those who ask because they test others' understanding, there are those who ask because they seek meaning, there are those who ask because they despise others, there are those who ask because they are straightforward, there are those who ask because they are deceitful, there are those who ask because their nature is weak, and there are those who ask because they rely on their own wisdom.
If one is asked by a weak person, one should answer by distinguishing.
If one is asked by someone who relies on their own wisdom, one should answer by asking in return until the question is exhausted, or sometimes answer oneself.
What is a debate with a set answer?
The answer is:
As the non-Buddhists went to the World-Honored One and asked in this way:
Shakyamuni Gautama!
Is the world permanent or impermanent?
The Buddha said:
This is not to be answered.
The question is:
Why did the Buddha not answer the question about the world being permanent or impermanent?
The answer is:
The non-Buddhists thought that the person is permanent, so they went to the Buddha and asked, Is the person permanent or impermanent?
The Buddha thought:
In the end, there is no person.
If I answer that there is no person, they will say:
I did not ask about existence or non-existence.
If I answer with permanence or annihilation, in the end there is no person.
What permanence or annihilation is there?
It is like a person asking another:
Good man!
Is the daughter of a stone woman respectful and filial?
They think:
A stone woman has no child.
If I answer that a stone woman has no child, they will say:
I did not ask about existence or non-existence.
If I answer that she is respectful and filial, a stone woman has no child, so how can she be respectful and filial?
They are also like this.
This question is not about reality, because it is neither existent nor real, so the Buddha did not answer.

Thus, [the views of] permanence and impermanence, both permanence and impermanence, neither permanence nor impermanence, the world having an end or not having an end, both having an end and not having an end, and neither having an end nor not having an end, should be understood in the same way.
He further asked:
Shamen Gautama!
Is the spirit the same as the body?
The Buddha said:
This is not a question to be answered.
The question said:
Why did the Buddha not answer this question?
The answer said:
The non-Buddhists took the body to be the spirit, went to where the Buddha was, and asked this question:
Shamen Gautama!
This body is the spirit, and so on, speaking in detail.
The Buddha thought like this:
There is a body but no spirit.
If I answer that there is a body but no spirit, they will say this:
I did not ask about existence or non-existence.
If I were to answer that the spirit is different from the body, there is definitely no spirit, so how can it be the body or different from it?
It is like a person asking another, Good man!
Are the horns of a rabbit and the horns of an ox equal and similar?
That person thinks like this:
Rabbits have no horns, but oxen have horns.
If I answer that rabbits have no horns and oxen have horns, they will say:
I did not ask about existence or non-existence.
If you say they are equal and similar, rabbits have no horns, so how can you say they are equal and similar?
It is the same with this question. Is this discourse existent or non-existent, true or false?
Because this question discourse is existent or non-existent, true or false, the Buddha did not answer.
The body is different from the spirit, it is also like this.
He also asked like this:
Shamen Gautama!
After the Tathagata's death, is he cut off or eternal?
And so on, extensively making four statements.
The Buddha said:
This is not to be answered.
The question says:
Why did the Buddha not answer?
The answer says:
The non-Buddhists, taking the self as originally non-existent but now existent, went to the Buddha and asked this question:
Shakyamuni!
Is this self originally non-existent but now existent, and then either permanent or annihilated?
The Buddha thought:
The self is ultimately non-existent, so how can it be originally non-existent but now existent, and then either annihilated or permanent? This question is neither existent nor real.
Because this question is neither existent nor real, the Buddha did not answer.
He further asked this question:
Shakyamuni!
Is it that one acts and one experiences oneself?
The Buddha said:
This is not to be answered.
The question said:
Why did the Buddha not answer?
The answer said:
The non-Buddhists take the self to create and experience the self, but the World-Honored One always says there is no self.
He further asked this question:
Shakyamuni!
Is it that others act and others experience?
The Buddha said:
This is not to be answered.
The question said:
Why did the Buddha not answer?
Answer:
The non-Buddhists say:
MaheÅ›vara creates, and I experience.
The World-Honored One always says that one experiences the fruits of one's own actions.
He further asked:
Shakyamuni!
Is there no creation and no experience?
The Buddha said:
This is not a question that can be answered.
The question is asked:
Why did the Buddha not answer?
The answer is:
The non-Buddhists say:
Suffering and happiness do not arise from causes.
The Buddha always says there are causes and conditions.
The question is asked:
The previous three answers correspond to the method of answering. How is this called answering the debate, up to not discussing a single sentence?
The answer is:
Although there is nothing to say, this is the fundamental answer to the debate.
Why is it so?
Because it corresponds to the principle of the answer.
Up to not speaking a single sentence, it is well understood in principle.
Sometimes there is silence and one wins in principle, let alone speaking and not winning?

Then ÅšatÄnÄ«ka said to the Venerable VÄá¹£pa:

VÄá¹£pa replied:

however, since you have come from afar, I will let you set forth the logical approach according to your wishes.
Then ÅšatÄnÄ«ka said this:

When VÄá¹£pa heard these words, he sat there in silence.
At that time, the disciples of Åšaá¹­hÄ«ra shouted, saying:
The Åšramaá¹‡a disciples of the Buddha have now fallen into defeat.

At that time, the Venerable Vá¹›jiputra said this:
Go well, if your teacher is Åšaá¹­hÄ«ra, he will know this matter himself.

It is like a woman who cannot give birth being called one with obstructed delivery.
